measured_by: 2-item subset of the Information Avoidance Scale
justification: “We assessed information avoidance with two items drawn from the eight-item information avoidance scale (Howell & Shepperd, 2016)… then averaged responses to the two items to form a single index.”
“Participants completed the eight-item information avoidance scale … we tailored to include items such as, ‘I would rather not know how much radon is in my house’. We averaged responses… α = .91.”

measured_by: single dichotomous choice: learn vs. avoid neighborhood radon level
justification: “Immediately after reading the burden manipulation, participants answered whether they would like to learn the radon level of homes in their neighborhood.”
“We included two checks on our burden manipulation: ‘Reducing radon would be burdensome for me,’ and ‘Reducing radon in my house would require more resources than I have,’ … averaged … α = .80.”

measured_by: single item ‘If officials recommend… how likely are you to leave?’
justification: “To measure expected behavioral response to a hurricane, we asked ‘If officials recommend that residents in your area evacuate because of a hurricane, how likely are you to leave?’”

measured_by: single item ‘If a hurricane were headed your way, how likely are you to spend at least $100 buying supplies?’
justification: “…and ‘If a hurricane were headed your way, how likely are you to spend at least $100 buying supplies?’”
“To measure perceived susceptibility to damage we asked, ‘How likely is it that your place of residence will experience damage from a hurricane in a given year?’”
“To measure anxiety about hurricanes we asked, ‘How anxious would you feel if you learned a hurricane will hit your county?’”

measured_by: single item ‘How much do weather reporters exaggerate hurricane danger?’
justification: “To measure perceived weather reporter credibility we asked, ‘How much do weather reporters exaggerate hurricane danger?’”
“Participants completed a brief measure of financial security (Shepperd, Emanuel, & Logan, 2018) that assessed participants’ perceptions of their ability to handle financial challenges.”
“To measure ability to afford repairs, participants indicated whether they could afford to repair their homes if their homes had high levels of radon (1 = Definitely Not; 10 = Absolutely).”
